docs.title: About

docs.text:
What is the composition of your crowd?


Primary
 audience and 
Secondary
 audience?


Identify the 
decision makers
, the 
opinion leaders
 or the 
gatekeepeers
.
Identifying these people will help you to better target your message.


Is the crowd mixed or homogeneous?






What are the relevant attributes of your crowd?


Age, gender, occupation, culture, education,...?


Approach them differently based on these attributes.






What does the audience know/think/feel/do (KTFD) about 
you
 and 
the subject/message
?


Know
 facts


Think
 perception/opinion


Feel
 emotions (positive, neutral or negative)


Do
 actions






What's in it for them? (WIIFT)


Lead with benefits and support with features. Give the audience actual advantages!


Benefits are often less technical and will be easier for the audience to digest and get behind.


Try to get the audience's attention and try to involve/persuade them.






Tip


Try to find fallacies in your audience's and your way of thinking so you can deal with them!
docs.title: Profile Audience

docs.text:
What is your initial credibility? (IC)


Rank


Expertise


Image


Goodwill/trust


Common ground






Tip


Try to emphasize your initial credibility!
docs.title: Initial Credibility

docs.text:
Describe your objective


General Objective
 (an overall goal)


Action Objective
 (an objective or single action)


Communication Objective


What do you want the subject to KTFD about you/subject 
after
 you've conveyed your message?
docs.title: Objective

docs.text:
Direct or indirect approach?


Use 
direct
 when the audience is receptive, eager, pleased, neutral,...


Use 
indirect
 when the audience will be resistant to the message, displeased, uninterested, unwilling to cooperate,..


Indirect:
 introduce yourself, refer to WIIFT, build interest/credibility,...






Tip


Put your main points/ideas at the beginning and end of your message!






Tip


Use an indirect approach when bringing bad news!




Pick a medium!




Written (document, text,...)


Positive:
 permanent and accesible, convenient, can be edited, time saving


Negative:
 difficult to convey emotions, who will read it and when?, no immediate feedback


Important:
 follow up your communication, it's hard to build personal relationships using the written medium






Oral (telephone, conference call,...)


Positive:
 can convey emotion, no permanent record


Negative:
 less precise, no permanent record, not much detail


Important:
 if not face-to-face, there is no body language






Blended (words and non-verbal cues, meeting, presentation + handout,...)


Positive:
 group relationship, control if/how/when the message is received, immediate feedback


Negative:
 time consuming, less precise, no permanent record
